widgets.html:
• thanks to Mikkel & Dylan
  • thanks to all of you for coming out this morning
  • introduce yourself
  • today I'm going to talk about:
    • FLOSS: Free, Libre, Open Source Software
    • what these terms actually mean
    • what FLOSS could mean for an art practice
    • why I think floss is the future

• definition
    • free: as in speech, not beer
    • libre: related to above
    • open source: source code is available
      • not the same as free/libre
    • software: we will talk about non-software
  • FOSS exists

• some history
    • early days of computing
    • Free Software Foundation / GNU
  • richard Stallman
  • linus torvalds
  • licenses

• these are tools I regularly use in my workflow:
    • SuperCollider - sound synthesis, composition
    • Open Stage Control - building controllers/instruments/slideshows
    • lilypond - notation, engraving
    • Processing - visual processing, synthesis
    • GIMP - image processing
    • neovim - text editor for code
    • Joplin - note taking app
    • FluCoMa - machine listening, machine learning, data processing
    • flucoma demo

widgets.onDraw:
ctx.fillStyle = cssVars.colorFill
ctx.globalAlpha = cssVars.alphaFillOn

var sliderWidth = width / value.length - 1
for (var i in value){
    ctx.beginPath()
    ctx.rect(i * width / value.length, height, sliderWidth, - value[i] * height)
    ctx.fill()
}

widgets.html:
• I like to code, but being a programmer is not a prerequisite for engaging with FLOSS
    • GIMP
    • vital
    • ardour
    • qlc+

10:40


  • I'd like to close by
  • XF encourages us to transcend our biology via tech
  • XF's three pillas according to Hester:
    • technomaterialism
    • anti-naturalism
    • gender abolistionist
  • in a music/composition context,I've been exploring these ideas via IEMs: tuning/metronomes
  • Ryan Hammond's Open Source Gender Codes (OSGC)

10:43

  • A friend recently sent me an essay from 2008 by American Anthropogist David Graeber wherein he critiqued a panel discussion held at the Tate Modern
  • four contemporary philosophers talked about art and labour in the art economy

  • "Perhaps communism has always been with us. We are just trained not to see it. Perhaps everyday forms of communism are really...the basis for most significant forms of human achievement, even those ordinarily attributed to capitalism. If we can extricate ourselves from the shackles of fashion, the need to constantly say that whatever is happening now is necessarily unique and unprecedented...we might be able to grasp history as a field of permanent possibility, in which there is no particular reason we can't at least try to begin building a redemptive future at any time."

  • he's suggesting that maybe we already have the tools we need for revolution, we just need to change our perspective

10:45


  • With that I'd like to encoruage all of us to consider the tools we use in our work and how they may contribute to a radical future

widgets.onDraw:
ctx.fillStyle = cssVars.colorFill
ctx.globalAlpha = cssVars.alphaFillOn

var sliderWidth = width / value.length - 1
for (var i in value){
    ctx.beginPath()
    ctx.rect(i * width / value.length, height, sliderWidth, - value[i] * height)
    ctx.fill()
}

widgets.html:
"Perhaps communism has always been with us. We are just trained not to see it. Perhaps everyday forms of communism are really...the basis for most significant forms of human achievement, even those ordinarily attributed to capitalism. If we can extricate ourselves from the shackles of fashion, the need to constantly say that whatever is happening now is necessarily unique and unprecedented...we might be able to grasp history as a field of permanent possibility, in which there is no particular reason we can't at least try to begin building a redemptive future at any time."


-David Graeber
2008
